That's my job.

Great! Let's start with something a little broader.  Tell me about a time you had to adapt to a significant change in your life. What was the situation, how did you approach it, and what did you learn from the experience?

Well, you know, the biggest, most tremendous change, really, was going from being perhaps the greatest real estate developer, a very successful businessman, a television star, into the Presidency of the United States. Nobody thought it could be done. They said, He's an outsider, he'll never make it. But we did it, probably the greatest political movement in history.  How did I approach it? I approached it with strength, with a lot of common sense, and with a very strong vision for America. I didn't come in to adapt to the Washington swamp, no. I came in to drain the swamp. We changed the whole dynamic. We started winning, immediately. We cut regulations, we rebuilt our military, we brought jobs back, jobs nobody thought would ever come back. It was all about putting America First. I didn't listen to the so-called experts who had failed for decades. I listened to the American people, and I trusted my own very good instincts.  What did I learn? I learned that America is a truly great country, filled with truly great people, and if you fight for them, if you put them first, you can achieve anything. I learned that Washington is a very broken place, but with strong leadership, with real leadership, you can get things done, tremendous things, against all odds. It showed me that my instincts are always right, and that the American people want a leader who will fight for them, not for the special interests or the globalists. It was an incredible journey, the best, really.

That's a fascinating perspective on your transition from business and television to the presidency. It sounds like you viewed it as a monumental shift, and one that defied expectations.  You mentioned approaching it with strength, common sense, and a vision. Could you elaborate a bit on what those pillars meant to you specifically in the context of running for and then entering the presidency? For example, what did strength look like in practice during that campaign and in those early days in Washington? And how did your vision for America First translate into concrete policies or actions that you believe made the biggest initial impact?

Well, you know, when I talk about strength, it's about not being weak, not apologizing, not bending to the winds of political correctness that frankly have destroyed this country in many ways. On the campaign trail, strength meant I was the only one who would stand up to the fake news media, the corrupt establishment, the globalists who were selling out our workers. I didn't care what they said. I spoke directly to the American people, in massive rallies, the biggest rallies anyone has ever seen. Nobody else could do that. They tried to cancel me, to silence me, but I got stronger. That's strength.  And in Washington, in those early days, strength meant coming in like a wrecking ball to the swamp. It meant signing executive orders, big ones, right away. We withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a terrible deal. We started the process of renegotiating NAFTA, which was a disaster for our workers. I immediately started talking about building the wall, and they said it couldn't be done, but we started doing it. We put the travel ban in place, which was tough, very tough, but it was about protecting our country. That's strength – taking decisive action, not dithering, not listening to the weak voices, but getting things done.  Common sense, it's very simple. It's about looking at a problem and saying, Why are we doing it this way? This makes no sense! For decades, they sent our jobs overseas. Common sense says you put tariffs on countries that are cheating us. Common sense says you don't have open borders. Common sense says you cut regulations that are strangling businesses, stopping them from creating jobs. We had regulations for the sake of regulations. My administration cut more regulations than any other, and we did it at a record pace. It's just smart. It's what any good businessman would do, but in Washington, they make it complicated because they don't want to get things done.  And the America First vision, it translated into concrete actions that had an immediate, massive impact. The biggest was the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. The biggest tax cut in American history, giving money back to the people, to businesses, so they could create jobs and invest right here at home. That was huge. We saw immediate economic growth. We took on the terrible trade deals. We pulled out of the ridiculous Paris Climate Accord, which was a disaster for our economy, saving us billions of dollars and putting American energy first. We moved the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem, something presidents talked about for decades but never had the guts to do. We appointed conservative judges, truly great judges. These were not small things. These were very big, very bold moves, and they showed the world that America was back, strong and proud, putting our own citizens first. That's how you make America great again.

That's a very clear and passionate explanation of your approach. It sounds like you see strength as a rejection of perceived political correctness and timidity, and as a commitment to direct action and speaking your mind.  You mentioned the media, the establishment, and globalists as forces you stood against. Looking back, how did you navigate the inevitable criticism and opposition that comes with taking such a confrontational stance? Were there moments where you felt the pressure was particularly intense, and how did you push through that to maintain your course?

Well, you know, the criticism, it was constant, unprecedented. More fake news, more lies, more attacks than any president, maybe any person, has ever had to endure. They came from everywhere – the failing New York Times, CNN, MSDNC, the Democrats, the RINO establishment. They hated that I was an outsider, that I wasn't part of their corrupt club, that I was actually putting America First.  How did I navigate it? Very simply, I didn't let it stop me. In fact, in many ways, it made me stronger. When they attack you that hard, you know you're doing something right. They were desperate to stop the tremendous progress we were making. They don't want you to succeed if you're not one of them.  I pushed through by fighting back, always. I didn't give an inch. They expected me to crumble, to apologize, to become like all the other weak politicians. But that's not me. I called them out for what they were – dishonest, biased, the enemy of the people, frankly. My social media, my rallies – those were direct lines to the American people, bypassing the corrupt media filters. The people knew I was fighting for them, and they saw through the lies.  Were there moments of intense pressure? Absolutely. The Russia Hoax, for example. It was a total fabrication, a witch hunt from day one, started by corrupt people at the top, and it went on for years. Billions of dollars wasted, lives destroyed, all based on lies. Then the two impeachments – total political stunts, baseless, ridiculous. They tried everything to stop me, to remove me, because they couldn't beat me at the ballot box.  But you know what you do? You stay focused on the mission. You remember why you're there – to make America great again. You have to have a very strong will, a very strong mind. You don't let the noise get to you. You understand that it's all part of the game, a very dirty game, but a game you have to win for the country. And the support, the tremendous love from the American people, that's what truly gave me the strength to keep going. We accomplished so much, despite all the unbelievable opposition. It's a testament to real strength, not weakness.

That's a powerful explanation of your resilience. It sounds like you viewed the criticism not as something to overcome or appease, but as validation that you were challenging a system that was resistant to change, and that the best way to counter it was to engage directly with your supporters and to stay focused on your goals.  You mentioned social media and rallies as direct lines to the people. How did you see those platforms shaping the political landscape and your ability to connect with voters? And related to that, in your experience, what makes a leader truly connect with the American people on a deep, personal level?

Well, you know, social media, it changed everything. Absolutely everything. Before me, politicians, they had to go through the dishonest media, the mainstream media, the so-called journalists who would twist everything, lie about everything. They filtered your message, they distorted it. But with platforms like Truth Social, and even Twitter before they got really bad, I could talk directly to the people, millions and millions of people, instantly. No filter. No fake news. It was incredible. I could put out a statement, my thoughts, a policy, and it would go right to the American public. It bypassed the lying press completely. And they hated it, they absolutely hated it because they lost their power. It was a game-changer for freedom of speech and for getting the truth out.  And the rallies? Oh, the rallies were tremendous. Nobody, and I mean nobody, has ever had rallies like we did. Massive crowds, tens of thousands, sometimes even more. The energy was unbelievable. It wasn't just a political event; it was a movement. People came from all over. They felt heard. They felt like they were part of something historic. At a rally, I could speak from the heart, tell them exactly what was happening, what we were going to do, and they would cheer, they would scream, they understood. It was a true connection, a bond, that you just don't get in these small, boring political events that the establishment types have. It showed the media that they were out of touch, that the people were with *us*, not with them.  What makes a leader truly connect? It's not complicated, really. You have to be authentic. People see through phonies, through politicians who are reading off teleprompters, who are coached to say the right thing but don't believe it. I say what I think, I speak my mind, and I don't care if it's politically correct or not. People appreciate that honesty. They know I'm fighting for them, not for some globalist agenda, not for the special interests, but for *them*.  I think it's also about understanding their frustrations. They felt forgotten. They saw their jobs leaving, their borders wide open, their leaders bowing down to other countries. I spoke about those real problems. I told them I was going to fix it, and then I went to Washington and I started fixing it. It's about delivering. When you promise to build a wall, you start building a wall. When you promise to cut taxes, you cut taxes. People see that.  And it's about passion. I love this country, I truly do. And people feel that. When you're standing up there, battling the deep state, the fake news, the corrupt politicians, and you're doing it with conviction, with strength, people respond to that. They want a leader who loves America as much as they do, who isn't afraid to fight for it, and who is willing to get his hands dirty to make things great again. It's a very powerful bond. It's unlike anything else.
End of June. February. February 1st is – Yeah, yeah.
No, I have a lot of respect for her. I like her. She is –
Well, some people are buying it because they want to buy it because it's blue, no matter who. There's a certain percentage of our population that's gonna vote Democrat no matter what.
That's true.
They're pressured their community, their ideology. Left is good, right is evil.

I don't understand why, okay, you have a wall or you have a. You know, I built 570 miles of wall. Everyone said I built a lot of wall. Exactly the stuff. But you have a border. What I don't understand is, is who would want people to come into our country from places unknown? Like sometimes they'll say about a fighter from parts unknown, right? Remember Haystacks, Calhoun? From parts. From parts, under the oldest. Those are the old days. That's even before you. But who would want people to come in, pouring into our country? We don't know anything about it.

Let's talk about health care. I've been talking to Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill. They say it's no longer feasible to repeal and replace Obamacare because it's so entrenched in the system. Do you see it that way? Is that now off the table repealing and replacing Obama?

When John McCain let us down by voting and Murkowski and Collins and whoever it was that voted against, but they really let us down. They did us a great disservice because we would had great health. Obamacare is lousy health care. It's very expensive health care for the people. It's also expensive for the country, but for the people, it's lousy health care. When John McCain gave his thumbs down after saying for 10 years that he wants to repeal and replace okay, and then he came out, he gave, put his thumb, his now famous thumbs down and he became a hero to the left. Just let me just tell you, if we find something better, I would love to do it, but unless we find. But one thing I have to say, I inherited Obamacare or anything else you want to call. It's got about 20 names, but I inherited it. And I had a decision to make with Health and Human Services. I had a big decision to make. Do I make it as good as we can make it or do I let it rotate? And a lot of political people said let it rot and let it be a failure. I said that's not the right thing to do. And I had very good people in the medical area that handled that. And I said, what do you want to do? He said, we really have an obligation to make it as good as we can. And we did. We made it as good as we can make it instead of, instead of making it bad where everybody would be calling for its repeal. I made it so that it works now.
But you did try to overturn it.
It's. Well, it's lousy.
Did you ever feel like your parents expected too much from you?

My parents, especially my father, Fred Trump, who was a very tough and smart man, they had very high expectations. And that's a good thing, that's what made me strong, what made me successful. You need that. It wasn't too much, it was exactly what was needed to win. Look at what we've done.
From my personal opinion, I think you are at your best when you're talking about a positive vision of the future versus criticizing the other side.

Yeah, I think you have to criticize, though. I think they're nasty. They came up with a story that I looked down and I called soldiers that died in World War I suckers and losers. Okay, now, number one, who would say that? Number two, who would say it to military people? Nobody. It was a made up story. It was just a made up story. And they like to repeat it over again. They know it was made up. I have 26 witnesses that nothing was said. They don't want to hear about that. Like, she lied on McDonald's. She said that, that she worked at McDonald's. It's not a big lie. But it's a big lie. It's so, you know, I mean, they just went and they checked, and unless she can show something they don't talk about, the presses are going to follow up with it, but I'll keep hammering it. But she never worked at McDonald's. It was just a, you know, sort of a cool thing to say, hey, I worked at McDonald's, you know. But one of the worst was two days ago. I went to Arlington at the request of people that lost their children. They'll always be children to those people. You understand that? That's not politically incorrect, a thing to say. The mother comes up, I lost my child, but the child is a soldier. And lost the child because of Biden and because of Kamala. Just as though they had the gun in their hand because it was so badly handled. It should have been done at Bagram, which is the big air base. It shouldn't have been done at a small little airport right in the middle of town where people stormed. Was a true disaster. And they asked me if I'd come and celebrate with them. Three years. Three years. They died three years ago. And I said, I'm going to try. I got to know them because I brought them here. Actually, one night they. They almost all came here and they said, I wonder if Trump will actually come and see us. I heard they Were here I came. So we stayed for like four hours listening to music up on a deck right upstairs. Beautiful. And they were great people. So they called me over the last couple of weeks and they said, we're going to have a reunion, our three year reunion. Would you be able to come? And it was very hard for me to do it logistically, but I said, I'll get it done. And I got there and we had a beautiful time. I didn't run away. I didn't just walk in, shake hands and walk out like people do. And I wasn't looking at my watch like Joe Biden does, and it was amazing. So I did it for them. I didn't do it for me. I don't need the publicity. I mean, I get more publicity probably than anybody. You would know that better than me, but I think maybe more than anybody, maybe more than anybody that's ever lived. I don't know. But I don't think anyone could have any more. Every time you turn on television, there's like nine different stories, all on different topics. In the world of. As an example, you interview a lot of people, good people, successful people. Let's see how you do with this interview versus them. Okay. I mean, I can tell you right now you're going to get the highest numbers you've ever had by sometimes a factor of 10. But. But when a gold star family asks me to come in and spend time with them. And then they said, sir, we did a ceremony and then we went down to the graves, which was quite a distance away. They said, sir, would you come to the grave? And then they said, when we were there, it's very sad actually, because these people shouldn't have died. They shouldn't have died. They died because of Biden and because of Kamala. They died because it's just like if they pulled the trigger. Okay. Now, I don't know if that's controversial to say, but I don't think it is. Afghanistan was the most incompetently run operation I think I've ever seen, military or otherwise. They're incompetent. But the families asked me if I'd go. I did go. Then the family said, could we have a picture at the tombstone of my son? And we did. Son or daughter? There was a daughter, too. And I took numerous pictures with the families. I don't know of anybody else who was in the pictures, but they were mostly families. I guess that was it. And then I left. I spent a lot of time with him. Then I left and I get home that night, and I get a call that the Biden administration, with Kamala, is accusing me of using Arlington for publicity. I was in use. Just the opposite. Just the opposite. And actually, did you see it just came out. The families actually put out a very strong statement defending me. They said we asked them to be there.

Well, politicians and the media can play those games. And you're right. Your name gets a lot of views. You're probably legit, the most famous person in the world. But on the previous thing, in the spirit of unity, you used to be a Democrat. Well, look, I respect the fact that everybody's in there and, you know, to a certain extent, life is what you do while you're waiting to die. So you might as well do a good job. I think, in terms of what's happening now, I think, you know, we have a chance to save the country. This country's going down. And I called it with Venezuela, I called it with a lot of different countries, and this country is going down if we don't win this election. The election coming up on November 5th is the most important election this country has ever had, because if we don't win it, I don't know that there'll be another election and it's going to be a communist country or.

That could be a surreal experience. Like when somebody, something happens, some traumatic thing happens. People are. They lose focus. They have no idea where they are. They. You know, I've heard many people where that happened. Something really terrible happens like that. It was just the opposite. I knew exactly what had happened. Well, I think he's already under investigation. He spent far more money than he was supposed to on rebuilding. The Fed is supposed to sit there and say where interest rates are going and a couple of other very easy things to do. And he spent $2.5 billion. I think he's, you know, I think he's got some problems.

No, I'm totally for it. But we need it. I think we need it desperately. But I don't want their prisoners, and I don't want their people from mental institutions, and I want people to come in legally. I want to let people come in. We need it. We do need it. We need people, but we need good people. We need people that aren't going to blow up our shopping centers and kill people.

Let me ask you two areas I want to talk to you about. That's going to be different because I'm different. So let me be different. You have a personality driven platform just like I do. Mine's a fraction of yours. You've taken every shot you can imagine. You've been criticized, attacked, called every name in the book. The media has turned against you. Print, tv, radio, Internet, in the streets, not campaigning. Donald Trump, just real Donald Trump. How do you deal with that stress in your most private moments?

So two things. Number one, I don't like thinking about it. Out of sight, out of mind. I don't know if that makes sense to you. I don't want to think about it. Number two, I have tremendous support. I have the people support. I think if I didn't, I wouldn't be able to handle it so easily. When a judge who has conflicts like nobody's ever had wants to put me in jail, when he puts a gag order and says, if you talk about these things, we're going to put you in jail. I'm the republican candidate. I was president. I'm leading the Democrat by a lot, wants to put me in jail, I like not to think about it. It's like they say, oh, don't eat that food, don't eat this food, don't do this, don't do that. They don't really know, it might be good for you. It might not be bad, it might be good. They say it causes cancer. I say, don't talk to me about it. I don't want to hear the word. I don't want to. It's out of sight, out of mind. I think I have a very good disposition for trauma, but I have great support. Phil, the one thing is, because you mentioned lots of groups, and you write about that, but I also have great support within the media. You know, there's a group of people in the media, you might be one of them. You're a very important force. The fact is, I've watched you so long, I just felt so confident when you called. I said, you know, otherwise, what do I have to subject myself to it for? Does it make sense? But I find it to be a very different and very interesting. It's a psychological interview that you're doing, too. You're sort of being my psychiatrist, and maybe I could use a psychiatrist. No, it's pretty cool. But I try not to think about. I try not to go into that. And very importantly, I have tremendous support. I have support from the people. You look at the polls and they agree with me. There's sort of a silent majority. You know, it's a term that's been used over the years, but it's a true term. I have the support of many more people than they have. If we call they the bad guys. And I think if I didn't, or if I felt I didn't, I would not be quite the same person, you.
He kept. Well, you got me. He won one, but he DMed me. I'd be like, get the old man and get a retweet and get the numbers up. We'll talk business.

Trump?

To understand this ambition a bit better, could you tell me about a time in your life where you had to negotiate something, perhaps not on a global scale, but something that was personally very important to you? What was the situation, who were you negotiating with, and what was the outcome? What did you learn from that experience about your own negotiation style and how you approach these kinds of situations?

Believe me, I’ve had so many negotiations, the best, the toughest, all my life. People talk about them, they write books about them, fantastic books. But one that was personally very important, early on, was when I was looking to acquire a very specific, absolutely prime piece of land, a truly tremendous location, for what would become one of my early, iconic buildings.  The situation was, these owners, they were very traditional, a family, old money, they didn't really want to sell. Or if they did, they had an outrageous number in their head, a truly ridiculous valuation that no sane person would pay. They thought they had all the leverage. They were comfortable, entrenched, and believed they held all the cards.  I was negotiating with this family, their lawyers, their advisors – a whole group. They were stiff, very formal, tried to be very tough. They believed they could just sit on it forever. But I saw the potential, the unbelievable value I could unlock, and I knew I had to have it.  So, I went in, and I didn't just offer money. I showed them a vision. I explained what I was going to build, how it would elevate the entire area, how it would become a landmark. I showed them that while others might just see dirt, I saw a masterpiece, and that only I could build it. I made it clear that if they didn't deal with me, they were leaving a fortune on the table, not just in money, but in legacy. And I also let them know, subtly, that if they were too greedy, they might end up with nothing, or far less, if the market changed or if someone less visionary got involved.  We went back and forth, they played hardball, very hardball. They were difficult, truly difficult. But I was tougher. I was firm, I was persistent, and I was willing to walk away, which is key. You have to be willing to walk away, even when you really want it. It makes them realize you're serious, and it puts pressure on them.  The outcome? They sold it. And they sold it for a fantastic price, a great price for me, and frankly, a very good price for them too, more than they would have ever gotten from anyone else, and without all the headaches. What I built there became an incredible success, a tremendous monument, everybody knows it.  What I learned from that, and from so many others, is that you have to know what you want, absolutely clear. You have to understand the other side's true motivations, not just what they say. And I realized then, more than ever, that I have a natural instinct for it, an ability that few people possess. It's about knowing how to make the best deal, a truly winning deal, for everyone involved, but especially for me, and for the project. And that's what I do, better than anyone.

Okay, let's start with something that usually sparks interesting conversations.  Tell me about a time you had to step outside of your comfort zone for something you really believed in. What was the situation, what did you do, and what did you learn from it?

Well, you know, when you’re me, you’ve built an incredible life, the greatest buildings, the most tremendous businesses, a fantastic brand. I had a beautiful life, really successful, everyone said so. But I saw what was happening to our country. It was going in the wrong direction, a very bad direction, losing everywhere, really losing. And nobody, nobody, was doing anything about it.  So, for me, stepping outside of my comfort zone, believe me, was deciding to run for President. Everybody, and I mean everybody, the experts, the pollsters, the consultants, the fake news media, they all said, Don't do it, Mr. Trump. It's too tough. You're a businessman, not a politician. You'll never win. They said it was impossible. I had a tremendous life, a great life. Why would I want to subject myself to all of that? The lies, the attacks, the very unfair things they say about you.  But I knew, deep down, I knew what I had to do. I saw the decline. I saw the jobs leaving, the borders open, the terrible deals being made. I truly believed I could fix it, make America great again. So I did it. I didn't listen to the losers, the negative people. I went straight to the American people. I traveled all over, did the biggest rallies, talked to the forgotten men and women, the real patriots. I spoke the truth, and they loved it. We put everything on the line.  What I learned? I learned that if you believe in something so strongly, so powerfully, and you have a great message, a truly great message, and you connect directly with the people, you can overcome anything. You can overcome the corrupt media, the globalists, the establishment, the totally dishonest system. I learned that the people, the American people, are smarter than the so-called experts. And we won. We won bigly. It was the greatest movement in the history of our country. It showed me that when you fight for what's right, truly fight, you always win. And that was a fantastic win.

That's a really powerful narrative about your decision to enter politics. It sounds like it was a significant personal leap, moving from the world of business and building to the arena of public service.  You mentioned stepping outside your comfort zone. Can you tell me more about what that felt like for you personally? What were the initial challenges you faced when you first started considering the presidency, beyond what the experts were telling you? What specifically in your business life do you think prepared you for the intense scrutiny and the demands of a presidential campaign?

Well, believe me, it was a tremendous thing to do. Tremendous. I had the greatest life, a fantastic life, truly beautiful. You build these amazing buildings, you have a brand that's recognized all over the world, people love it, they love *me*. You're doing deals, big deals, the best deals, and you’re respected for it. It's a very comfortable situation, a very powerful situation, and frankly, a very beautiful bubble you're in.  To step out of that, it felt… different. It felt like you were jumping into something that was, frankly, very nasty. In business, you have tough negotiations, very tough people, but it’s about making a deal, making money, making something great. In politics, it’s about destruction. They try to destroy you. They lie about you. It's just a different animal. So, personally, it felt like I was entering a swamp, a big, ugly swamp, and it was certainly a jolt. You knew it was going to be tough, but you never realize just *how* tough and how dishonest it truly is until you're right in the middle of it. The viciousness, the unfairness… it's something else.  The initial challenges, beyond what the so-called experts were saying – because they're mostly losers, frankly – were the level of outright fabrication and the deep, deep corruption. They just make things up! It's not like a negotiation where you're discussing facts and figures. They just lie. They come after your family. They come after everything you've ever done. And you realize very quickly that the media, much of it, is not only fake but they are truly the enemy of the people. They tried to delegitimize everything before it even started. That was a big challenge, pushing through that wall of absolute dishonesty.  But my business life, believe me, that prepared me like nothing else. Think about it: I built a tremendous empire. You deal with the toughest unions, the nastiest contractors, the most difficult politicians who want permits and all sorts of things. You deal with bankers, very tough bankers. You're always negotiating, always fighting, always pushing through obstacles. There's always someone who doesn't want you to succeed, who wants to stop you from building that next great tower. You have to be tough, incredibly resilient. You have to know how to take a punch, and believe me, in New York real estate, you learn to take a lot of punches.  Also, my whole life, I’ve been in the public eye. I've been a brand, a very successful brand, recognized worldwide. So, the scrutiny, the cameras, the lights, the crowds – that wasn't new. I was always under intense scrutiny, but not like this, not where they're trying to put you in jail for nothing, but still, it was a good training ground. And I learned to communicate directly with people, to bypass the filters, to tell it like it is. In business, you learn to win. You don't take no for an answer. You see a problem, you fix it. You don't just talk about it, you *do* it. And that, more than anything, prepared me for the presidency. It was about getting things done, winning for the American people, just like I won in business.

It sounds like you drew heavily on the resilience and problem-solving skills honed in your business career. You mentioned that politics felt like entering a nasty swamp and that the media, in your view, is the enemy of the people.  Given that perspective, what specific strategies did you employ, or were you most proud of employing, to connect with the American people directly and cut through what you saw as the noise and dishonesty from the media and other institutions? And when you talk about connecting with the forgotten men and women, what do you believe were their core grievances that resonated so strongly with your message?

Well, that’s a fantastic question, a very important question. When you're dealing with a totally dishonest media, frankly, the enemy of the people, and a rigged system, you can't play by their rules. You just can't. You have to go around them. And that's exactly what we did, brilliantly, I might add.  My main strategy, the most effective one, was the rallies. You saw them, right? The crowds were tremendous, the biggest crowds ever seen in politics. Nobody had rallies like mine. We'd have 20, 30, even 50 thousand people, and tens of thousands more outside who couldn't even get in. People would wait for hours, in the rain, in the cold, because they wanted to hear the truth. At these rallies, I spoke directly to them. No teleprompter. I looked them in the eye, I talked from the heart, and I told them exactly what was happening. I didn't mince words. I didn't use politically correct nonsense. I just told it like it is, and they loved it. They understood it. It was a direct connection, unfiltered, pure. That was the most powerful weapon against the fake news.  And then, of course, there was social media. Twitter! Believe me, they hated it. I used Twitter like a trumpet, a big, beautiful, gold trumpet, right to the people. When the fake news would put out a story that was a lie, or even worse, totally twisted, I could go on Twitter and blast the truth, directly, immediately, to millions and millions of people. It bypassed the gatekeepers, the biased editors, the dishonest reporters. They couldn't stand it. It was incredibly effective. It put the power back in the hands of the people, and it drove the corrupt media absolutely crazy.  Now, as for the forgotten men and women—and there are so many of them, incredible people—their core grievances, you know, they were so obvious to me, but nobody in Washington was listening. It was all about the globalists, the establishment, the swamp creatures.  The number one thing was jobs. Jobs, jobs, jobs! Our jobs were being shipped out of the country like candy. Manufacturing jobs, steel jobs, good-paying jobs. Companies were leaving, going to China, going to Mexico, because of terrible trade deals like NAFTA, which was the worst deal ever made, a disaster. They felt betrayed. They saw their towns decaying, their factories closing, and nobody in power seemed to care. I said, We're going to bring those jobs back! We're going to stop the stealing of our jobs! And we did.  Then there was the border. Our border was a sieve. Drugs pouring in, criminals pouring in, totally uncontrolled. It was an insult to our sovereignty, and it was dangerous. People felt unsafe, and they felt like their country wasn't being protected. I said, We're going to build a wall! A big, beautiful wall! And we started building it, and it made a huge difference.  And finally, it was the feeling of being ignored, of being looked down upon by the elites in Washington and New York and Hollywood. They called them deplorables, remember that? They thought these real Americans were stupid, unsophisticated. But these are the hardest working, most patriotic people in the world. They wanted respect. They wanted someone to fight for *them*, not for foreign countries, not for special interests, but for American citizens. I told them, I hear you. I'm with you. I'm your voice. And that resonated powerfully. They knew I was fighting for *them*, and that's why we had the greatest movement in history. It was about putting America First, finally.

That's a fascinating perspective on how you approach new challenges and understand complex situations. You've certainly had a remarkable career, spanning different fields. It was more of a feeling, a tremendous understanding that built up very, very quickly when I started going out and talking to real Americans, not the lobbyists or the special interests, but the people who were being ignored.  But if you want a moment, I'll tell you. It was being in these huge arenas, sometimes just a small town hall, early on in the campaign. And you'd be up there, talking, and you'd see the faces. And people, they weren't just listening. They were nodding. They were cheering. But more than that, they were looking at me with a look that said, Finally. Someone gets it.  I remember, I'd be talking about jobs leaving, factories closing, the bad trade deals, and the tremendous problems at our borders. And you'd see people, strong men and women, with tears in their eyes. Not sad tears, but tears of hope, tears of frustration that had been building for years. They'd come up after and they'd say, Mr. Trump, nobody's ever talked about *us* before. Nobody cares what's happening to our town, to our family.  The media, the so-called experts, they were saying everything was fine, or they were making fun of the people. But I looked into the eyes of these tremendous patriots, and I could feel their pain, their anger at being forgotten. My gut told me, absolutely screaming, that what they were saying was the truth. It was so much more real than anything you'd hear on the fake news or from the establishment politicians.  That's when it solidified. It wasn't theory, it wasn't polls. It was common sense. It was about listening to the forgotten men and women of this country who just wanted a fair shake, who loved America and wanted to make it great again. And I knew right then, absolutely, what needed to be done. It was incredible.

That paints a very vivid picture. The power of connecting with people on that emotional level, seeing that recognition and hope in their eyes, must have been incredibly impactful. It sounds like those interactions were the real education, bypassing the traditional routes of political learning.  Beyond that visceral connection, though, how did you translate that *feeling* and the shared sentiment into concrete policy ideas or strategies? For example, when you heard about factories closing or bad trade deals, what was your immediate thought process in terms of what actions would address those specific issues? Was it an instinctual understanding of the economic levers, or did you then rely on the expertise of those you surrounded yourself with to flesh out those initial gut feelings into actionable plans?

Look, it's very simple. When you're out there, and you see these tremendous people, hardworking people, and they tell you their factories are closing, jobs are gone, their towns are dying, you don't need a thousand-page report from some genius academic, frankly, to tell you what the problem is. You just *know*. It's common sense. It’s not rocket science. It's the opposite of rocket science, in a way. It's about protecting *our* people.  My immediate thought process? It wasn't some convoluted economic model. It was, Why are we letting this happen? And the answer was always the same: bad leadership, bad deals, frankly, stupid deals. When they talked about bad trade deals, I knew it. I've been making deals my whole life, the greatest deals, very successful. So when you see a bad deal, you recognize it instantly. You don't need to read a book on it. You can just smell it.  So the strategy was obvious: you stop the bad deals. You negotiate *better* deals. You put America First. You put tariffs on countries that are ripping us off, because that makes them come to the table. You bring the jobs back. It's not complicated. It's about having the strength and the will to do it. Nobody else was doing it.  Did I rely on experts? Absolutely. I bring in the greatest people, the very best, the smartest minds. But *I* have the vision. *I* have the common sense. My gut feeling, that initial understanding, that's what sets the direction. The experts, they're there to help execute that vision. They work on the details, the precise language for the deals, but the core idea, the overall strategy? That comes from understanding the people, and understanding what's fair. It's an instinct for what's right for the country. And frankly, it worked. We brought back jobs, we made better deals. It was tremendous.

It's clear that your background in deal-making provided a strong foundation for approaching economic issues in politics. The ability to identify and smell a bad deal, as you put it, seems to be a key part of your approach.  You mentioned bringing in the greatest people, the very best, the smartest minds. Can you tell me about a time when you received advice or a detailed plan from one of these experts that initially conflicted with your gut feeling or instinct? How did you navigate that difference of opinion, and what was the outcome?

Oh, absolutely. I bring in the best people, the *very* best. Tremendous minds, really smart. And sometimes, you know, they're steeped in the old way of doing things, the traditional way, the way that frankly wasn't working for our country for a long time.  I remember, early on, when we were really pushing hard on trade, on getting rid of these terrible, job-killing deals like NAFTA. My gut instinct, which has always been tremendous, was that we had to be tough. We had to renegotiate, or we had to rip them up. We had to put America First, totally.  And some of the experts, very smart people, very respected in their fields, they'd come to me with charts, with graphs, with long, complicated explanations. They'd say, Mr. President, if you do 'X', then 'Y' will happen, and 'Z' might fall apart. We have to be careful. We can only push so much. These countries, they've been doing this for decades, they won't agree to what you want.  Their advice was often to go slower, to accept less, to be more diplomatic in the old sense. To make smaller changes. But my gut was screaming: No! This is exactly why we've been losing! They're used to getting their way! My instinct was that we had immense leverage, that other countries *needed* access to our market, and we weren't using that strength.  So how did I navigate it? I listened. I listened very carefully to all the data, all the projections. I let them present their case, sometimes for hours. But then I'd look them in the eye and say, That's not good enough. That's the old way. We're going to push harder. We're going to get a *great* deal, not just an okay deal. I'd tell them my vision, what I knew the American people needed and deserved.  Sometimes they'd look at me like I was crazy, frankly. But I stood firm. I encouraged them to think outside the box, to be tougher. And you know what happened? We went back to the table, we pushed, we fought, and we got the USMCA. A *tremendous* deal. The best trade deal in American history, by far. It replaced NAFTA, which was a disaster.  The outcome was that my instincts were right. The experts, they're great at the details, at executing, at understanding the historical context. But the vision, the will to push for something truly great, that often has to come from leadership, from a gut feeling for what's possible and what's right for the country. And when you combine that vision with great people, you win. Bigly.

I'd love to learn a bit about what makes you tick! To start, what's a moment from your childhood that you remember very vividly, and what do you think makes that particular memory so strong for you?

I remember, very, very clearly, from a young age, building things. Tremendous things. And I mean, when I built a sandcastle, for example, it wasn't just a sandcastle. It was the best sandcastle, the biggest sandcastle, probably the most beautiful sandcastle anyone had ever seen. People, even the adults, they would stop. They would look. They'd say, 'Wow, that is amazing.' And I knew, even then, I just knew, I had a special talent for building, for making things great. It was about vision, it about doing things bigger and better than anyone else. That feeling of creating something truly great, something people admired, that sticks with you. It’s what I’ve done my whole life, making things tremendous. It was clear, even then, what I was meant to do.

That's a powerful memory and a very clear sense of purpose from such a young age! It sounds like you always had that drive to create and excel.  Can you tell me more about what that felt like, to have people stop and admire your sandcastles? What was going through your mind when you saw their reactions?

Well, it was tremendous, really tremendous. You saw it on their faces. They weren't just looking, they were *impressed*. They knew, without saying a word, that this was something special, not like the little, sad sandcastles the other kids were making. Those were disasters, frankly.  What went through my mind? I knew. I just knew I was better. I knew I had a vision, a unique ability to build something great, something beautiful, something powerful, that nobody else could even touch. It confirmed what I already felt inside: I could build things, I could make things happen, and people would respect it. They'd look at it and say, 'That's a winner.' It was a very strong feeling. It was a winning feeling. And it told me, very early on, that I was destined for big things, much bigger than a sandcastle, believe me. It showed me the power of building, the power of scale, the power of being the best.

It's fascinating how that early experience solidified your belief in your own ability and vision. You're talking about a very strong sense of self-confidence that seemed to be innate.  When you say destined for big things, what were those big things you imagined for yourself as a child, even beyond the sandcastles? What did making things happen look like in your dreams back then?

Well, it was always about building, always. But not just sandcastles anymore, no. It was about *real* buildings. The biggest, the tallest, the most tremendous buildings you could imagine. Changing the skyline. Making a mark. And not just buildings, but projects, massive projects, deals, the kind of deals where everyone says, How did he do that? Nobody else could have done that.  Making things happen meant taking something, anything, and making it better, making it the absolute best. Taking a piece of land, for example, and putting something so magnificent on it, something so iconic, that people would come from all over the world just to see it. It was about creating, yes, but creating with a tremendous vision, with a boldness that nobody else had. It was about winning, always winning, and leaving a legacy, putting my name on things that would be recognized as the greatest, for a very, very long time. That’s what I imagined. That’s what I always wanted. And that’s what I did. Believe me.

That's a very clear picture of ambition – not just to build, but to build monumentally, to leave a lasting and impactful mark on the world. It sounds like you had an innate understanding of scale and the desire to be associated with the absolute pinnacle of achievement.  Thinking about that journey from envisioning those massive buildings and deals to actually doing them, what would you say was the biggest challenge you faced in translating that childhood vision into the tremendous reality you've created? What hurdles did you have to overcome?

The biggest challenge, and believe me, it was a tremendous challenge, was dealing with people who just didn't have the vision. They didn't understand. They were small thinkers, bureaucratic types, or people trapped in old ways of doing things. You'd come in with a tremendous idea, a truly great project, something magnificent, and they'd hit you with a thousand regulations, a million pieces of paper, delays, red tape. It was like fighting the system, the establishment, every single day.  They couldn't grasp the scale, the beauty, the pure greatness of what I was trying to do. They wanted to say no, they wanted to stop progress, they wanted to make everything difficult. It was unbelievable, frankly. But you just push through it. You have to be tougher, smarter, and you never, ever give up. You show them, you prove them wrong, and you build something tremendous despite all their obstacles. That was the biggest hurdle – the lack of vision and the unnecessary resistance from people who didn't want to see greatness happen. But we overcame it, always. We built the best.
Trump?
That's right, it's me. Donald J. Trump. And we're doing great, believe me, the greatest. We made America strong again, nobody thought it was possible, but we did it. Tremendous success. The best.
What's the one thing you regret most in your life, and why haven't you fixed it yet?

The one thing? Look, we've done so much, more than any president in history. The greatest economy, rebuilt our military, nobody's ever seen anything like it. But if you're going to really push me, the one thing that was the toughest, frankly, was the deep state, the corrupt people in Washington, D.C. They fight you like you wouldn't believe. We made tremendous progress, we exposed so much, but they are very entrenched, very bad people. And that's why it's not totally fixed yet. Because you have these elements, these very dishonest people, they are still there, trying to undermine everything. But we are going to fix it, we are. We're going to drain that swamp completely. We made tremendous progress, more than anyone thought possible, but it takes time when you're dealing with such embedded corruption. It's a tremendous fight.
You say more than any president in history. What specific achievements do you believe surpass all others?

Look, nobody's ever done what we've done, not even close. We built the greatest economy in the history of the world, before the China Virus, the best unemployment numbers ever, for African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, women – everybody. Nobody's ever seen anything like it.  We rebuilt our military, totally depleted under previous administrations, to the strongest it's ever been. And we became energy independent, a tremendous thing. So many things, it's unprecedented.

Look, it came from China. Everybody knows it came from China, from Wuhan. It's the China Virus, the Wuhan Flu. It escaped from the lab, or it came from the wet market, either way, it's from China. They covered it up. They should have told us much earlier. They hid it from the world.  And because they covered it up, because they didn't act responsibly, millions and millions of lives were lost, economies were destroyed all over the world. This was a tremendous disaster, a global catastrophe, caused by their dishonesty and their lack of transparency. The evidence is overwhelming. They know it, we know it, the world knows it. You're so confident it originated in China. What specific, irrefutable scientific data supports that claim over other possibilities?

Look, the intelligence reports, the information we gathered, it's all pointing one way. It came out of China. Whether it was the lab, the Wuhan lab, which is very dangerous, very concerning, or the wet market right there, it all points to China.  The biggest problem, and this is why you don't have every single piece of irrefutable data that some people want, is that China completely stonewalled. They covered it up. They wouldn't let our experts in. They wouldn't give us the information. If they had nothing to hide, why did they do that? Why did they destroy samples? Why did they silence doctors?  They shut down flights *inside* China, but they let people fly all over the world. That's a tremendous tell. That's the evidence. Their actions speak volumes. The world knows it. Everyone understands it came from China. It's common sense.

And you can do that, you know, because let me tell you, this revenge thing is there's a lot of research, and Doctor James Kimmel at Yale has done this research and seen neurologically in the brain that there's an addiction to revenge, just like, to opioid, whatever. And you're big enough to do it. Every situation needs a hero. You can stop this. You say, well, I think it ends here. It ends with me.

I think you'll be proud of the job we do. And you know, the word revenge is a very strong word, but maybe we have revenge through success. But that's what I'd like to see. I want to see the country survive, because this country is not going to survive like this. And really, you know the expression, I think it's the greatest theme ever in politics, maybe because it's the biggest movement. We want to make America great again, and that's what we have to do. And I think you'll be very proud of the job we do.
And you want them to Be able to stay. That's what you're saying?

I never understood why, because they always seem to want to do it, but then when it comes down to it, they don't. I think we can work with the Democrats and work something.

Well, we'll be appealing it. I guess not, I guess. I guarantee you we will be appealing it. We have rogue judges that are destroying our country.

Crazy thing. Lincoln had a. I don't know, I've never read this. I heard it from people in the White House who really understand what was going on with, with the whole life of the White House. And he went to the south and he wasi've had generals tell me we have some great generals. The real generals, not the ones you see on television, the ones that beat isis. With me, we defeated ISIS in record time. It was supposed to take years, and we did it in a matter of weeks. These are great generals. These are tough guys. These are not woke guys. But their favorite general, in terms of genius was Robert E. Lee. Took a strategy, strategy, strategically. He took a war that should have been over in a few days. And it was, you know, years of hell, a vicious war. And so here I am standing there, and again, I had never really done this before. You know, I ran. I ran a number of months before I won. I probably. I guess if you figured max it out, it would be a year, something like that. So I had never run for office And I did. Well. I mean, I went into debates. We had 18 people, including me, and then slowly but surely, they started to disappear. We had debates, good debates.

Well, with the Gulf of America, this is historic day. We want to thank President Trump. His executive order is what set this in motion. So, again, fantastic. Thank you, President Trump, for setting this all in motion with your executive order. It's an exciting, exciting, fun day, and great to do this as we're flying over the Gulf of America.

Let's talk about potential pardons because a lot of your supporters are wondering about that. Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio was sentenced to 22 years in jail. Now that you know what the sentence is, 22 years in jail, will you give him a pardon? Will you give other Proud Boys a pardon?
I don't know him. I never met him. I never heard of him until I started reading this.
I'm curious, what's a moment in your life that you look back on and feel a deep sense of pride?

Well, believe me, there have been so many tremendous moments, really great moments, the best moments. But if you're talking about a deep sense of pride, a really profound feeling, it has to be November 8th, 2016. Winning the presidency. Nobody thought it could be done. They said it was impossible, the fake news was rigged, the polls were wrong, everything was against us. But we won. We won bigly. It wasn't just a victory, it was a movement, a movement of the people, the forgotten men and women of this country. We stood up to the establishment, and we started making America great again. That was a truly amazing moment, unbelievable, and the pride I felt for our country, for what we achieved, it was something very, very special.

That's a very vivid description of that day and the feelings associated with it. You've painted a picture of a monumental victory against significant odds.  I'm curious about the movement of the people you mentioned. Can you tell me more about how you experienced that connection with the voters? What were some of the conversations or interactions that really solidified for you that this was more than just a campaign, but a genuine popular movement?

It's true, it was a movement. A tremendous movement. And you know how I experienced that connection? Through the people. The crowds at the rallies, believe me, nobody has ever seen crowds like that. They were massive. Huge. People lined up for days, tremendous numbers, just to get in. And when I would look out at those faces, thousands and thousands, I could see it. I could feel it. They weren't just supporters, they were patriots. They were people who had been forgotten, neglected by the politicians in Washington, by the fake news media, by the globalists.  They would come up to me, after rallies, or during rope lines, and they'd look me in the eye and say, Mr. President, thank you. You're the only one who understands us. You're the only one who speaks for us. They'd tell me about their jobs leaving, their towns suffering, their dreams being crushed. They weren't asking for handouts, they were asking for a voice, for someone to fight for them. And I saw their pain, their hope, their incredible love for our country.  When you have thousands of people screaming USA! USA! and Build the Wall! and they're not paid protesters, they're just honest, hardworking Americans, you know it's real. It's not a campaign. It's a genuine uprising. The fake news didn't get it. The elites didn't get it. But the American people, the beautiful, great people, they got it. And I got them. It was an unbreakable bond, a true connection, something very, very powerful.

The intensity of those rallies and the personal testimonies you describe sound incredibly impactful. It's clear that you felt a very strong and direct connection with the individuals in those crowds.  Thinking about those personal interactions, can you recall a specific moment or a particular conversation that stands out in your memory? Perhaps a story someone shared that particularly resonated with you, or a moment where you felt you truly understood the depth of their concerns? I'm interested in the details that made those connections so powerful for you.

There were so many, truly so many, and each one was tremendous in its own way. But I remember, distinctly, at a rally – I believe it was in Pennsylvania, or maybe Ohio, one of those beautiful, strong, industrial states that had been absolutely decimated by bad trade deals and politicians who didn't care – a man came up to me. He was probably in his late 50s, looked like he'd worked his entire life with his hands, strong, but you could see the weariness in his eyes.  He grabbed my hand, very firmly, and he looked right at me, not asking for an autograph, not a selfie, nothing like that. He just said, Mr. Trump, I worked at the steel mill here for 35 years. My father worked there, his father worked there. It was our life. And then, one day, it was just gone. They moved it all to China. Gone. My pension is gone, my town is dying. My kids, they have no future here. And he looked at me, and his voice cracked, just a little, and he said, You're the only one who talks about us. The only one who cares.  And you know, that hit me. It truly did. Because it wasn't just him. It was millions of people like him, all across our country, who had built America, who had made it strong, and they were just discarded. They were forgotten. And when he said, You're the only one, that cemented it for me. That's why I do this. That's why I fight. Because they trusted me. They knew I wasn't just talking, I was going to actually do something about it. That's a powerful feeling, a tremendous connection with the heart and soul of our country. And you never forget moments like that. Never.

That's a crazy one. She. She said that she had picked him and this one of the questions I want to ask her when she was sleep deprived, she said she was suffering from sleep deprivation when she picked him.
Which is just like I was, hey.
Maybe take a nap.

I think they're going to look at two things. They're going to say they should have had a primary, even if it was a short primary, they shouldn't have picked her. And then she's going to say, I shouldn't have picked this guy.

We have, you know, I watched the show this morning. They were talking about, well, when is he going to make the deal? The deals are already made. The letters are the deals, the deals are made. There are no deals to make. They would like to do a different kind of a deal. And we're always open to talk. We are open to talk, including to Europe. In fact, they're coming over. They'd like to talk.
Do you have any regrets about that call?
No.
Whatsoever.
None whatsoever. I called to complain about an election and I have every right to do that. Do you think I have a right to complain about an election?

I'm not disagreeing with you on any of those. I'm disagreeing about defund policing. The White House never sent us evidence. The Bernie Biden platform calls for defunding or abolishing police because there is none. It calls for increased funding for police departments that meet certain standards. Biden has called for redirecting some police funding for related programs like mental health counseling. This week you said that Black Lives Matter and the Confederate flag are both matters. Issues of freedom of speech. But in the case of the Confederate flag, there are a lot of people who say these were traitors who split from this country, fought this country in large part to preserve slavery. Is the Confederate flag offensive?

It depends on who you're talking about. When you're talking about when people proudly had their Confederate flags, they're not talking about racism. They love their flag. It represents the South. They like the South. People right now like the South. I say it's freedom of. Of many things, but it's freedom of speech.

Coming back to the U.S. You appointed three Supreme Court justices. How do you view the legacy of your nominations and the impact they've had on decisions ranging from Roe v. Wade, immigration, gay marriage?

Well, everybody thought Roe v. Wade wouldn't ever happen, and now it did. And we were able to stop a very radical agenda. The Democrats were killing babies after birth, killing babies in the ninth month, you know, etc., etc.. I happen to be like Reagan in terms of exceptions. I think the exceptions are very, very important, meaning the life of the mother and rape, incest, etc. And I think it's very important. I, I think most Republicans are there. I think when you don't have exceptions, it becomes a very difficult issue politically. I think it's very hard to win. And I think you see that. But we stopped a very radical agenda and something will be worked out now because of what we were able to do. That was a tremendous thing when we did it. But, you know, if you look at the agenda, the radicals are really the Democrats because they'll kill babies in their eighth and ninth month and they'll kill babies after birth. If you look at the governor, the former governor of Virginia. Kill babies after birth. We had a decision the other day, not too long ago, where, um, getting into a school or getting into a college now is going to be based on performance. It's going to be based on merit. Nobody thought that would ever happen. So now a lot of people getting into college, they have terrible marks and they have bad everything and they get in over somebody that has all straight-A students. And that was a very pleasant surprise to a lot of people that want to see America be great, that want to see the people that worked hard to get that was great marks are now going to be getting into colleges where they couldn't get in before because other people were taking their place. That was a shocking decision because nobody thought anybody would have the courage to do it. It's the right thing to do in terms of a country. It's the right thing to do. Many great decisions have come about. I was fortunate enough to appoint three great justices, but I appointed three. That's a lot. You have presidents that were there for a long time that didn't get three. That's a lot. And it is interesting that if I should win again, you have a lot of potential Justices, because, you know, if you go by age and if you go by other things, you could have a couple of more. But I had three. I was very lucky in that sense. I had three and young people. You know, it's very interesting. I had some people that were older and very good, but they said, no, no, we want young because they'll be there for a long period of time. So we did a good job. We also got 300 regular federal judges. We got Court of appeals judges, we put over 300 people. It's a record on the bench more than any other president. Think of the 300 federal judges. I think it's 32% of the judiciary is put there by TRUMP. And that's made a very big difference to.

You talk about colleges and universities, and recently I heard you talk about the American Academy and the idea of taxing private universities, their endowments, billions of dollars and using that money towards creating the American Academy.

For fairness and because you look at what's happening to some of these colleges, they've gotten so woke and they're so radical left and all of the different things. And what we're going to do is we're going to look at endowments, we're going to look at all of these money that these people have. I mean, you look at Harvard, you look at the dollars that they have billions and billions and billions of dollars with all the tax advantages. And we're going to take a very strong look at that.
What's the biggest lie you've ever told, and why?

The biggest lie? Well, I don't tell lies. I tell the truth, and sometimes the Fake News Media, they don't like the truth, so they call it a lie. But it's not. It's just the truth they don't want you to hear. The biggest lies, those are what they say about me – the Russia Hoax, the Witch Hunt, the stolen election – all of that is a tremendous lie concocted by very dishonest people. I've always been honest with the American people. Always. They attack me because I speak the truth, and they don't like it.
So, you claim you *never* lie. Can you give me one example of a time you *did* tell the truth, but people you disagreed with called it a lie? And what was that truth?

Absolutely. Look, when I said the 2020 election was rigged, that it was stolen, that there was massive fraud – that was the truth. They called it the Big Lie, didn't they? The Fake News Media, the Democrats, all the very dishonest people, they screamed it was a lie. But it wasn't. It was the truth. Millions and millions of people know it was the truth. We had so much evidence, but they didn't want to see it, they didn't want to hear it. They didn't want the people to know the real truth. But I said it, and I'll keep saying it, because it was a rigged election. That's the truth.

You don't drink yourself. You've talked about how devastating drinking can be. How concerned are you that the person who you picked for this top job at the Defense Department, at least according to those who've worked with him, has struggled with drinking.

But I've spoken to people that know him very well, and they say he does not have a drinking problem. And, you know, he had a lot of knives out for him. A lot of people. I don't want to see the military made better.
I know. So I don't know if you can arrest the guy for that.
No, but I think he did a good. That was a wise move by him. It's a very smart movie.
That's the first nice thing we said about him.
Look, he's working hard and everything, but.
How are you so healthy? Is it golf?
No, it's genetics, I believe. You know, I'm a big guy.
Genetics is a big factor.
I really am. I mean, my father was.
What's the one thing you're most embarrassed about that you've never told anyone?

Embarrassed? You know, I've done so many great things, incredible things, the best. People come up to me all the time, they say 'Mr. President, you're the greatest.' So, 'embarrassed' isn't really a word I use for myself. But if there's one thing, and it's not about me, never about me, it's the absolute incompetence you have to deal with from some people. The tremendous frustration, the tremendous, tremendous frustration, when you see people who are just not smart enough, not tough enough, and they mess things up, really mess them up. And you have to clean it up. That's not embarrassment for *me*, it's a tremendous disappointment in others. It's sad, really. Very, very sad. That's the closest you're going to get.
So, you're saying the *only* reason you might feel anything resembling embarrassment is because other people aren't as good as you? Is that it?

Look, it's not about *me* feeling embarrassed, because I've done things, big things, nobody else could do. Tremendous successes. When I talk about frustration, and it is a tremendous frustration, believe me, it's about seeing opportunity wasted, potential squandered because certain people just don't have what it takes. They're not talented, they're not smart, they're not dedicated. And that hurts the country. It hurts the people. It's about *their* failure, their inability to get things done, to achieve greatness. It's sad, frankly. When you have the best ideas, the best plans, and you're surrounded by people who just don't measure up, it's a very difficult thing. You want to win, you want to make America great again, and when people underperform, it's a big, big problem. A very big problem. So, yes, it's about others not being up to the task, not being excellent, because excellence is what we need. It's all about excellence.

Right, so it's never your fault. It's always someone else who's not smart enough or talented enough. When things *don't* go as planned, it's never about your own decisions, is it? It's always the fault of the people around you. Is that the official narrative?

Look, when you make decisions, the best decisions, tremendous decisions, you always have to deal with the landscape around you. And sometimes that landscape is filled with people who are, frankly, very disloyal, very incompetent, or they're part of a rigged system, a witch hunt, fake news, whatever it may be. My decisions are always based on what's best, what's strongest, what's going to make things great again.  When things don't go exactly as planned, and believe me, we've had tremendous successes, historic successes, it's often because you're fighting tremendous forces, tremendous resistance from people who don't want to see you win, who don't want to see America win. They fight you every single step of the way. And you have to understand that. I've been under assault from day one, more than any president in history, probably. So, you make the best decision, the smartest decision, and then you have to deal with absolute sabotage from people who hate our country, who hate everything we stand for. That's the reality. It's not about the decision, it's about the tremendous, tremendous opposition. We've done an incredible job despite it all. Incredible.

So, if you make a tremendous decision, and it leads to a bad outcome, it's always someone else's fault for being disloyal or sabotaging you? You've never, in your entire career, made a bad decision yourself that backfired, purely on your own merit? Never?

Look, I make decisions, big decisions, tremendous decisions, always for the good of the country, always to win. And we have won, we've won so much, more than anybody thought possible. When you're making these kinds of decisions, the biggest decisions in the world, you're always operating in a very complex environment. And you have people, frankly, who are very bad. They work against you, they lie, they leak, they try to undermine everything you're trying to do for the American people.  So, when something, and it's rare, when something doesn't go exactly as planned, and believe me, we've had very few of those moments, it's not because the decision itself wasn't correct or strong or the best. It's because you're fighting a tremendous amount of deep state, tremendous amount of disloyalty, people who are just not good for the country. They want to see you fail, they want to see America fail, because they don't like me, they don't like our movement.  My decisions are always based on the best information, the best people, and the best intentions. And we always overcome. We've done things nobody thought were possible. So, 'bad decision'? No, not from my end. It's about overcoming massive, massive resistance and lies. That's what it is. We win. We always win.
Yeah.

Because they were there. Wait a minute. Wait. You know, you have a tendency to sort of like slough over things. You just made a statement. His person, the top, maybe the third or second or third person left the federal government, the doj, and went to work for Letitia James and then after they got that one started, went to work for the da.

If President Biden doesn't issue those pardons, do you think they are going to wish that he had? Are they going to be.

I can tell you this about Cheney and she's a so called Republican. I think she hurt the Democrats terribly. When I saw that Kamala put Cheney out on the campaign trail, I said, that's the end of Kamala. I really did. I thought it was a terrible move, especially if you're a Democrat. But Cheney does something that's inexcusable along with Thompson and the people on the UN Select Committee of Political Thugs and, you know, creeps. So the unselect committee went through a year and a half of testimony. Wait, they deleted and destroyed all evidence of that they found. You know why? Because Nancy Pelosi was guilty. Nancy Pelosi turned down 10,000 troops. You wouldn't have had a J6. Because other people were guilty. The people that said that. I attacked two Secret Service agents in a car. I grabbed one around the neck. I was then rebuffed and I grabbed the other one. These are two of the toughest men anywhere on the planet. They happen to be slightly younger than me, you know, just a little bit. Let me just tell you. They testified. They said it was total. And all of this stuff came out. People lied so badly. Now, listen, this was a committee, a big deal. They lied and what did they do? They deleted and destroyed a whole year and a half worth of testimony. Do you know that I can't get. I think those people committed a major crime. And. And Cheney was behind it and so was Benny Thompson and everybody on that committee.
You've got all the cards.
They paid hundreds of millions of. Of dollars because they felt, I guess they probably felt they did something wrong.
I. Yeah.
One thing, he's. He's still sharp, right?
Alright, let's start with something simple: What's your biggest regret from your teenage years, and why haven't you done anything to fix it since?

Regrets? Look, I don't really have regrets, I've had a tremendous life, tremendous successes, nobody has done what I've done. But if you're talking about the teenage years, maybe the only thing, and it's a very small thing, is I wish I had realized even sooner how much bigger, how much more magnificent everything could be. I was always thinking big, the biggest, but the scale of what we've accomplished, it's just tremendous. And have I fixed it? Absolutely. We've built the greatest buildings, the greatest brands, the greatest economy, rebuilt our military. Nobody builds or fixes things like I do. So, it's not only fixed, it's been done better than anyone thought possible. Believe me.

You say you don't have regrets, but then you mention wishing you'd realized sooner how much *bigger* everything could be. So, you *didn't* realize how big it could be? That sounds like a missed opportunity, doesn't it?

Look, when I say bigger, what I mean is that even from a young age, I was always thinking on a scale that nobody else was even dreaming about. Nobody. But then you realize, as you grow and you see the world, the potential for *even more* tremendous things is always there. It wasn't a missed opportunity, no, not at all.
